origin: Native to Rohtak, Hisar, Jind, and Gurgaon districts of Haryana; also found in parts of Western Uttar Pradesh and Rajasthan
horns: Smooth, glossy, somewhat horizontal; grow longer, curving upward and inward in bullocks
purpose: Dual-purpose — milk and draught
physical_traits: Strong, compact, graceful body; long and thin head; flat bony forehead; narrow face; small sharp ears; long slender neck; prominent dewlap, no naval flap; males have large hump; thin tapering tail with black switch; sturdy limbs with black hooves; well-developed udder and prominent milk veins
milk_yield: 1400–2300 kg/lactation; fat content 4.3–5.3%; age at first calving 40–61 months; inter-calving 13–18 months
color: Generally white or light grey; bullocks are dark grey
other_info: Evolved from several native breeds; hardy and efficient draught animal—can pull one-ton load at 2 mph for 20 miles; near threatened due to crossbreeding trends; conservation efforts by Haryana Livestock Development Board (HLDB) and Goshalas; current population ~16.5 lakh

origin: Originated from the Gir Forest and surrounding districts of the Saurashtra region, Gujarat
horns: Long, sweeping backward and spiraling upward
purpose: Gir is a dual-purpose breed mainly used for high-quality milk production and light draught work.
physical_traits: Large head with domed forehead and narrow face; long pendulous ears; hooded black-pigmented eyes; short glossy coat; whip-like tail; heavy build with docile temperament
milk_yield: High-yielding dairy breed; in India averages 1200–1800 kg/lactation; in Brazil can produce up to 62 liters/day
color: Red or speckled red and white; varied coat colors with dark pigmented skin
other_info: Gentle and affectionate with humans; highly disease-resistant; tolerant to heat; one of the best Indian dairy breeds; population of pure Gir cows declining (~3000 in Gujarat); exported to Brazil for dairy improvement programs

origin: Originated from Sahiwal district (Punjab, Pakistan); found in Haryana (Rohtak, Karnal, Hissar, Gurgaon), Delhi, and Western Uttar Pradesh
horns: Short and almost horizontal in females; longer and curving upward and inward in bullocks
purpose: Dual-purpose — milk and draught
physical_traits: Medium-heavy build; long narrow face; long drooping ears; sturdy long legs; compact barrel; thin short tail; big hump in males (136 cm at withers); females ~120 cm; quivering skin resists ticks
milk_yield: 1500–2200 liters/lactation; fat content ~4.5%; lactation period ~235 days
color: Reddish brown to deep red with white patches on neck and underline; males darker at extremities
other_info: Docile, heat- and drought-tolerant, parasite-resistant; high adaptability (exported to Africa & Caribbean); purebred numbers declining; promoted by Punjab’s “Sahiwal Cattle Society” for conservation and propagation

origin: Originated in Mahal Kohistan region (Sindh, Pakistan) — including Karachi, Thattha, and Dadu districts; found in Orissa, Tamil Nadu, Bihar, Kerala, and Assam
horns: Thick, short, curved horns emerging laterally with blunt tips; thick and stumpy in males, thin in females
purpose: Primarily dairy (milch) breed; also used for light draught and field work
physical_traits: Medium-sized, compact, well-proportioned body; broad flat forehead; medium face with black muzzle; moderate dewlap and sheath; short neck; round drooping hindquarters; black tail switch; capacious udder with medium teats; males 130 cm height, 450 kg; females 120 cm height, 320 kg
milk_yield: 1100–2600 kg/lactation (avg 1840 kg); up to 5450 kg in 300 days; fat 4–5.2% (avg 4.5%); lactation ~265 days
color: Deep red to reddish-brown or yellowish-red; darker in males on shoulders and thighs; occasional white patches on dewlap and forehead
other_info: Highly heat- and tick-resistant; docile temperament; steady worker bullocks; originated from Las Bela cattle; exported to 33 countries; population < 70,000 (2013); urgent conservation and genetic management needed

origin: Native breed originated from the former princely state of Vijayanagar, now part of Karnataka; predominantly found in Mysore, Mandya, Hassan, Bangalore, Kolar, Chitradurga, and Tumkur districts of Karnataka. Also known as the Mysore breed.
horns: Long, vertical, and backward-bending horns.
purpose: Best known for draught and trotting ability
physical_traits: Medium-sized and muscular body; long compact frame with slender legs; prominent bulging forehead; long tapering face with grey to black muzzle; males have large humps; thin, moderately developed dewlap; small tucked-up sheath; fine tail with black switch below hocks; males ~340 kg, females ~227 kg.
milk_yield: Average lactation yield ~540 kg; fat content ~5.7%; lactation length ~285 days; calving interval ~600 days.
color: Grey to dark grey with deep shading on fore and hind quarters; light grey markings on face, dewlap, and underbody.
other_info: One of South India’s best draught breeds; foundation for several southern breeds including Amrit Mahal; bred by professional breeders and cultivators; maintained under semi-intensive system; selectively bred by Karnataka government; herds maintained at Turuvekere and Hesaraghatta; commemorated by Government of India postage stamp (2000).

origin: Native to the State of Mysore in Karnataka; developed in the mid-1800s by the rulers of Mysore by crossbreeding the Hallikar, Hagalavadi, and Chithradurg breeds to create a hardy draught breed suited to the local terrain.
horns: Horns emerge close together from the top of the head, curve upward and backward, and end in sharp black points (“swords for horns”).
purpose: Primarily draught breed (used for transport and war purposes)
physical_traits: Majestic, compact, and muscular body; long tapering head with slightly bulging, furrowed forehead; small yellow-lined ears; thin dewlap and small sheath; well-developed hump (~8 inches in bulls); strong neck, broad loins, level back and rump; medium, well-proportioned legs; small, hard hooves; thin black skin with glossy short hair; average height 50–52 inches; noted for endurance and speed.
milk_yield: Average 1000–1200 kg/lactation; calving interval ~600 days; poor milking capacity overall.
color: Various shades of grey — from white to almost black; white-grey markings on face and dewlap; muzzle, feet, and tail switch black (lighter in older animals).
other_info: Developed as a war and transport breed by Mysore rulers; classified as gun and pack bullocks; wild temperament when unhandled, but highly efficient once trained; thrive on minimal food without losing stamina; on verge of extinction; small village groups and Kaval lands used for conservation; efforts by Animal Husbandry Department ongoing; requires stronger preservation measures; symbol of Mysore’s livestock heritage.

origin: Originated in Satara district of Maharashtra; also native to Ahmednagar, Sangli, Kolhapur & Solapur; found in Bijapur, Dharwar, and Belgaum districts of Karnataka; closely related to the Hallikar breed; includes nine subtypes (Atpadi, Mhaswad, Pandharpuri, Kosa, Harnya, Daphlya, Bramhani, Dhangiri, Nakli).
horns: Long, narrow horns sweeping back and upwards in a bow, tapering to fine points; typically black, sometimes pink.
purpose: Primarily draught (farm work, racing, transport).
physical_traits: Compact, muscular body with lean long face, tight skin, clear features; long narrow head with convex forehead bulge; small sideways-held ears (pale yellow inside); elongated small eyes with thick folds; height 4.5–5.5 ft; weight 350–450 kg; stout legs with black hooves; short neck with light dewlap; firm moderate hump in males; strong shoulders and hindquarters; tight sheath/navel flap; tail reaching hock joint; quick and spirited gait.
milk_yield: Low; considered poor milker compared to other breeds.
color: Generally grey-white; varies by subtype — Mhaswad & Atpadi Mahal types are grayish white (males darker on fore/hindquarters with grey-white facial spots); Tapti type is white with carroty nose/hooves; Nakli type gray with tawny tinge; newborns rust-red-headed, fading after birth; fine, short, glossy hair.
other_info: Known for speed, strength, and endurance in tropical, drought-prone regions; classified as “medium fast draught”; steady population decline due to low milk yield; selectively bred in Maharashtra (Hingoli, Jath, Junoni) and Karnataka (Bankapur); part of Rashtriya Gokul Mission for conservation under Livestock Development Boards (LDBs); Surabhivana supports preservation efforts.

origin: Native to Kangeyam taluka of Tamil Nadu — includes Erode, Karur, Namakkal, and Dindigul districts; also known as “Kanganad” or “Kongu”; conforms to Southern Indian Mysore type with some Ongole influence.
horns: Smaller variety: horns short, spreading apart, curving backward; larger variety: long horns curving out, back, and almost completing a circle at tips.
purpose: Primarily draught; adaptable to poor nutrition.
physical_traits: Compact, muscular, and active with short, stout legs; strong hooves and well-sprung ribs; moderate-sized head with prominent forehead; dark eyes with black rings; small erect pointed ears; well-developed firm hump; short thick neck; back short, broad, and level; thin dewlap extending to sternum; sheath tight; udder soft but small with fine texture and small teats; tail moderate with black switch; tough, fine-textured skin.
milk_yield: 18–20 litres during peak period (but considered poor milker overall).
color: Males generally gray with dark gray to black on head, neck, hump, and quarters (color fades in castrated males); cows white or light gray with deep gray markings on knees and above fetlocks; calves red at birth, turning white or gray by 3–4 months; skin strong, tight, and dark-pigmented; hair fine and short.
other_info: Robust, drought-tolerant draught breed; known for endurance and adaptability to harsh, low-nutrition conditions; smaller variety found in Kangayam, Dharampuram, Udmalpet, Pollachi, and Erode; larger type in Karur, Aravakurchi, and Dindigul; bred in purity by Pattagars of Palayakottai; Senapathy Kangayam Cattle Research Foundation (Erode, Tamil Nadu) works actively for breed conservation; facing decline due to crossbreeding policies.

origin: Native to Bargur hills in Anthiyur Taluka, Erode district, Western Tamil Nadu; raised by Kannada-speaking Lingayats of the region; also known as “Semmarai” in Tamil Nadu.
horns: Thin, light brown horns emerging close at roots, inclined backward, outward and upward, curving sharply forward at the tips.
purpose: Dual-purpose (draught + milk); well-suited for hilly terrain.
physical_traits: Medium-sized, compact, tight-skinned body; well-shaped long head tapering to muzzle; moderately broad forehead; short horizontal ears; moderate hump; well-arched ribs; short dewlap; tight sheath; medium legs; short tail with brown switch; small cylindrical teats; small udder closely attached; inconspicuous navel flap; males avg 126 cm height, females 116 cm; strong brown/black hooves; agile and alert temperament.
milk_yield: 2–3 litres/day; 250–1300 kg/lactation (avg ≈ 350 kg).
color: Typically red with white patches; coat varies from cherry red to light red; full white or reddish brown also occur; skin red; hair short, straight, fine, brown and white; muzzle and eyelashes brown; hooves brown or black.
other_info: Hardy, fiery, and aggressive temperament; highly adapted to hilly and forested terrains; known for speed, endurance, and trotting ability; used in “Jallikattu” bull-taming sport; maintained in semi-wild forest enclosures (“Pattys”) under zero-input systems; Surabhivana Gaushala and other organizations engaged in conserving this native breed; scientific breeding programs underway to enhance milk yield.

origin: Native to Thanjavur, Thiruvarur, and Nagapattinam districts of Tamil Nadu, India; originated in Umblachery village (Nagapattinam); also known as Jathi Madu, Mottai Madu, Molai Madu, or Therkathi Madu.
horns: Black, short, pointed, medium-thick horns; bullocks are typically dehorned (unique regional practice).
purpose: Draught breed; used for ploughing, carting, thrashing, and paddy-field work.
physical_traits: Medium-sized, docile cattle; short erect ears; slightly broad forehead with shallow groove and white star; small black hooves (sometimes white); medium-sized hump (larger in bulls); strong legs; short thin dewlap; small bowl-shaped udder; teats small and well apart; long tail tapering below hock; compact body with tight skin; males 268–297 kg, females 219 kg; males 112–117 cm height, females ~105 cm; heart girth males ~150 cm, females ~135 cm.
milk_yield: ≈ 494 kg/lactation; fat content ~4.94%; lactation length ≈ 245 days.
color: Calves red or brown at birth turning grey with age; bullocks dark grey with black extremities; cows grey with lighter shade on face, neck, and hip; white markings on face, limbs, and tail (leg markings resemble socks); black muzzle and eyelids; white or partly white tail switch.
other_info: Distinct for dehorning and ear pruning of bullocks at 10–12 months; capable of working continuously 6–7 hours under hot sun; ideal for marshy paddy fields; declining population due to crossbreeding and habitat shrinkage; conservation farms at Orathanadu and Korukkai (Tamil Nadu); government and local efforts ongoing but need strengthening.

origin: Originated from Pulikulam village, Sivaganga district, Tamil Nadu; breeding tracts in Madurai, Sivaganga, and Virudhunagar districts; also known as Palingu Maadu, Mani Maadu, Jallikattu Maadu, Mattu Maadu, or Kilakattu Maadu.
horns: Long, extended horns curved outward, upward, backward, and then inward with sharp pointed tips widely spaced apart.
purpose: Draught and game breed; used in ploughing and traditional Jallikattu events.
physical_traits: Small-sized, compact, strong-bodied, and active; short legs; narrow dark face with tight skin; small pointed ears; prominent forehead with central groove; dark large hump in males, smaller in females; thick dewlap; short penis sheath flap; strong legs and feet adapted for running; udder small and not well-developed; males ~259 kg, females ~208 kg; male height ~117 cm, female height ~112 cm; body length males ~119 cm, females ~114 cm; chest girth males ~150 cm, females ~139 cm.
milk_yield: ~0.5–3 kg/day; average ~1.25 kg/day; calving interval 1.5–2 years; first calving at 4–4.5 years.
color: Males are dark grey; females are white or grey; white markings on forehead, limbs, and tail; muzzle, eyelids, hooves, and tail switch are black.
other_info: Maintained as migratory herds by traditional Konar and Thevar communities; lifespan ~20 years with 8–10 calvings; only 10–15% of cows milked for home use; population declined from ~45,000 (2006) to ~7,500 (2013); conservation efforts led by SEVA (Sustainable Agriculture and Environmental Voluntary Action), Madurai; vital for organic farming and rural livelihoods.

origin: Originated from Alambadi village on the banks of river Kaveri, Dharmapuri district, Tamil Nadu; also found in Erode district and hilly regions of upper Kaveri basin (Mettur, Pennagaram, Kollegal, Bangalore rural). Believed to have descended from Hallikar breed of Mysore. Bred mainly by Konga Vellalas, Lingayats, Vanniyars, and Vokkaligas.
horns: Sweeping horns curving backward and ending in sharp points.
purpose: Draught breed; used for agricultural work and transport.
physical_traits: Medium to large size with deep, compact body and loose frame; well-arched ribs, heavy shoulders, tight skin; dark moderately long head with narrow face and prominent bulging forehead; short thick neck; broad thick dewlap; small pointed ears; large well-developed hump; small to medium penis sheath; medium long tail tapering to black switch; short strong legs; large hard feet with prominent coronary band; narrow sloping hindquarters; males ~347 kg, females ~282 kg; male height ~124 cm, female ~115 cm; male body length ~134 cm, female ~124 cm; chest girth males ~167 cm, females ~155 cm.
milk_yield: Moderate yield; milk quality fair but generally poor milkers.
color: Coat varies in shades of grey, dark grey, black, and fawn; some with flesh-colored or dark skin with black muzzle; white markings on forehead, limbs, and tail.
other_info: Highly heat-tolerant and disease-resistant; can survive on forest grazing and dry fodder; semi-wild lifestyle (July–January in forests, penned at night); calving interval 16–24 months; provides manure for agriculture during harvest seasons; population critically low and nearing extinction; decline due to crossbreeding, mechanization, and loss of grazing land; conservation urgently needed to preserve this rare native breed.

origin: Originated from the Thar Desert of Rajasthan; native to Tharparkar district of southeast Sindh (now in Pakistan); also found along the Indo-Pak border in western Rajasthan and extending up to the Rann of Kutch in Gujarat.
horns: Lyre-shaped horns curving gradually upward and outward; males have thicker, shorter, straighter horns.
purpose: Dual-purpose (milk and draught breed).
physical_traits: Medium-sized, strongly built, deep-bodied cattle with straight limbs and good feet; average height ~138 cm; males ~408 kg, females ~350 kg; head medium-sized with broad, slightly convex forehead; full bright eyes with black eyelashes; long broad semi-pendulous ears facing forward; fine mellow skin with moderate dewlap; firm moderate hump (larger in males); semi-pendulous sheath in males; variable prominent navel flap in females; light shoulders; comparatively short legs; hard black hooves of moderate size; active and alert carriage.
milk_yield: ~2000 kg per lactation (≈ 7–8 litres/day under good care).
color: Generally white or gray with black shading on neck, hump, and hindquarters; light gray stripe along the backbone; coat deepens in color during winter and pregnancy; black, red, or mixed color variants occasionally occur.
other_info: Highly drought- and disease-resistant; hardy under extreme desert conditions; age at maturity ~36 months, first calving ~45 months, calving interval ~410 days; thrives even under heat and feed scarcity; selected as part of National Agriculture Development Programme for expansion in Tamil Nadu; cattle transported from Jaisalmer to Chettinad adapted well, producing 7–8 litres milk/day; Surabhivana Gaushala supports conservation and promotion of this resilient native dual-purpose breed.

origin: Originated from the Kankrej district of North Gujarat, India; also known as Bannai, Nagar, Talabda, Vaghiyar, Wagad, Waged, Wadhiar, Wadhir, or Wadial.
horns: Strong lyre-shaped horns covered with skin higher up than in other breeds.
purpose: Dual-purpose: valued for both milk and powerful draught work.
physical_traits: Large, heavy yet active and strong cattle; broad forehead slightly dished at center; large pendulous open ears; short face with slightly upturned nose; medium-thick, darkly pigmented, loose skin; thin but pendulous dewlap; males have prominent but less firm humps; shapely legs with small, round, durable feet; sleek coat; black tail switch.
milk_yield: Fair milk producers; good lactation yield for dual-purpose breed.
color: Coat color ranges from silver gray to iron gray or steel black; males usually darker on forequarters, hump, and hindquarters; hair soft and short with black tail switch.
other_info: One of the heaviest and most prized Indian cattle breeds; highly resistant to tick fever and other diseases; excellent heat tolerance and pest resistance; bulls commonly used for agricultural and road transport work; foundation breed for the Guzerat cattle in Brazil and similar strains in Latin America and the USA; known for stamina and endurance in hot climates.

origin: Originated from the coastal districts of Guntur, Prakasham, and Nellore in Andhra Pradesh; reared across Kurnool, Cuddapah, and parts of Mahabubnagar; developed under farmers’ care in the deltas of Penna, Krishna, and Godavari rivers.
horns: Short, stumpy horns growing outward and backward; thick at base and firm without cracks.
purpose: Dual-purpose: valued for both milk and draught work (ploughing and cart pulling).
physical_traits: Large-sized cattle with loosely knit frames and long bodies; short neck; long, muscular limbs; broad forehead; elliptical eyes with black ring and eyelashes; deep and wide chest; strong legs with straight toes; short tail with sloping tail head; moderately long, slightly drooping ears; large fleshy dewlap hanging to navel flap; slightly pendulous sheath; erect, well-developed hump in bulls; bulls weigh ~500 kg, 1.5 m height, 1.6 m length, 2 m girth; cows weigh 432–455 kg.
milk_yield: 600–2518 kg per lactation; ~5% butterfat; lactation lasts about 279 days.
color: Glossy white coat; some males have grey markings on hump and hindquarters; skin medium-thick, mellow, elastic with occasional black mottled markings.
other_info: First Indian cattle breed to gain global fame; known for toughness, rapid growth, and disease resistance; exported widely to tropical countries (Americas, West Indies, SE Asia, Australia); saved South American cattle population during “mad cow disease” crisis; now endangered in India due to mechanization; ICAR running conservation programs for pure Ongole bulls.

origin: Originated in areas drained by the Krishna, Ghataprabha, and Malaprabha rivers across Bijapur, Bagalkot, and Belgaum districts of Karnataka; formerly extended to Satara, Sangli, and Solapur (Maharashtra) and Raichur (Karnataka); now mainly found in northern Karnataka. Developed through crossbreeding of Gir, Kankrej (Gujarat), Ongole (Andhra Pradesh), and Mysore-type cattle.
horns: Medium-sized horns emerging from the side of the poll, curving outward, upward, and inward with pointed tips.
purpose: Dual-purpose: used for draught/agricultural work and moderate milk.
physical_traits: Docile and friendly temperament; massive body with deep, broad chest; short body with large barrel; short, thick, powerful legs with soft hooves; males ~145 cm height, 153 cm body length, 196 cm chest girth, ~550 kg weight; females ~122 cm height, 132 cm body length, 168 cm chest girth, ~325 kg weight; narrow face with broad, bulging forehead and shallow central groove; small curved horns; small, pointed ears; short thick neck; well-developed pendulous dewlap and slightly pendulous sheath.
milk_yield: 900–1200 kg per lactation (~300+ days).
color: Predominantly gray-white; males often darker on fore and hindquarters; females lighter; variations include brown-white, black-white, and mottled coats.
other_info: Breed population has declined by ~90%; NBAGR and BAIF are running conservation projects in native tracts; awareness programs organized for preservation; Surabhivana Gaushala participates in the national movement to conserve native ‘Desi’ breeds by providing shelters and promoting protection of Krishna Valley cattle.

origin: Originated from the Marathwada region of Maharashtra; also found in adjoining parts of Karnataka and Andhra Pradesh. Developed over ~200 years from a mixture of Gir, Dangi, and local cattle strains.
horns: Medium-sized, thick, wide apart, emerging sideways with blunt tips.
purpose: Dual-purpose: good milk yield and strong draught bullocks for intensive cultivation.
physical_traits: Medium to large build; masculine and alert head; prominent broad forehead; long drooping ears with curved tips; clean, straight, powerful limbs with black symmetrical hooves; well-developed hump; deep wide chest; thick pendulous dewlap; bulls weigh 620–680 kg, cows 432–485 kg; height ~134 cm (bulls), ~122 cm (cows).
milk_yield: 880–1580 kg per lactation (~300 days); ~4.3% butterfat.
color: Three color variations — Wannera (white with black sides of face), Balankya (white with black spots on lower body), and Shevera (white with irregular black spots). Head color varies: black & white in Wannera/Shevera, fully white in Balankya.
other_info: Tough, disease-resistant, and well-adapted to tropical drought areas; reared mainly on grazing lands; KVAFSU (Bidar) runs conservation programs to improve the Deoni breed.

origin: Originated on the Island of Jersey, a small British island in the English Channel off the coast of France; one of the oldest pure dairy breeds (~600 years old).
horns: Usually small, curved horns; often dehorned for management.
purpose: Pure dairy breed—renowned for high butterfat and milk solids; highly efficient milk producer per body weight.
physical_traits: Small, refined, compact build; cows weigh 800–1200 lbs; bulls 1200–1800 lbs; both sexes darker at extremities.
milk_yield: Produces 13× its body weight in milk per lactation; average 4.84% butterfat, 3.95% protein.
color: Varies from light gray/mouse color to dark fawn or almost black; commonly darker around hips, head, and shoulders; medium shades preferred; dark tongue and tail switch typical.
other_info: Adaptable to varied climates globally; excellent grazers; docile yet alert; bulls less docile; widely used to improve milk efficiency worldwide.

origin: Originated in Frisia, a region spanning the Netherlands and northern Germany; developed as a specialized dairy breed in the Netherlands and refined in North America.
horns: Usually short, curved horns; many are dehorned for safety and management.
purpose: Specialized dairy breed, dominant in industrial milk production worldwide.
physical_traits: Large, tall, robust build; cows weigh 680–770 kg; calves 40–50 kg at birth; deep barrel; well-developed udder; straight back.
milk_yield: ~10,220 kg milk per year with 3.7% butterfat and 3.1% protein.
color: Distinctive black-and-white or red-and-white piebald markings; each cow has a unique pattern.
other_info: Most widespread dairy breed globally; cornerstone of modern dairy industry; adaptable but high feed and management requirements.

origin: Originated in the north-eastern part of Switzerland, particularly the canton of Schwyz; one of the oldest dairy breeds in the world.
horns: Found in both horned and polled varieties; short, white horns darken at the tips.
purpose: Dual-purpose (dairy and beef); highly valued for milk and cheese production.
physical_traits: Medium to large-framed cattle; cows weigh 500–700 kg; bulls 800–1100 kg; strong limbs; long lifespan (12–15 years).
milk_yield: 6000–9000 liters per lactation with 4% butterfat and 3.5–3.9% protein.
color: Typically light brown, ranging from silvery-gray to dark brown; creamy white muzzle, dark nose, and dark-blue eye pigmentation.
other_info: Renowned for docility, longevity, and adaptability; ideal fat-protein ratio for cheese; fertile and disease-resistant.

origin: Developed in Denmark from local cattle crossed with Angeln cattle; spread across Europe and tropics for crossbreeding.
horns: Generally horned, with short, forward-curving horns.
purpose: Dual-purpose breed used for both milk and meat production.
physical_traits: Medium-to-large framed cattle; cows weigh 550–650 kg, bulls 900–1000 kg; strong frame; deep chest.
milk_yield: 8,000 kg per lactation; 4.17% butterfat and 3.5% protein.
color: Solid red coat varying from light reddish-brown to dark mahogany; often with white markings on the udder and tail.
other_info: Hardy, disease-resistant, and adaptable; known for fertility, longevity, and high-quality milk and meat.

origin: Originated in India, primarily in Haryana and Delhi; also found in Punjab and Western UP; exported worldwide for improvement programs.
horns: Short and tightly coiled, set close to the head.
purpose: Primarily a dairy breed, also valued for breeding and improvement programs.
physical_traits: Massive body; broad hips; compact structure; strong frame; well-developed udder.
milk_yield: 1003–2057 kg per lactation; average 1752 kg; 6.9–8.3% fat.
color: Usually jet black, occasionally with white markings on the tail switch.
other_info: High milk fat, adaptability, and international demand; improves productivity and disease resistance in other breeds.

origin: Originated in Surat district of Gujarat, India, with breeding tract extending over Vadodara, Bharuch, Kheda, and Surat.
horns: Flat, sickle-shaped horns turning upward at the tips.
purpose: Primarily a dairy breed, known for high milk fat and efficient feed conversion.
physical_traits: Medium-sized and lighter body; compact, active, well-proportioned; straight back; fine limbs.
milk_yield: Average 1667 kg per lactation with 7.02% fat.
color: Coat varies from rusty brown to silver-grey or black; skin is black or brown.
other_info: Known for high milk fat and SNF content; low feed intake; ideal for small farmers in low-input systems.

origin: Originated in the Saurashtra region of Gujarat, particularly around the Gir Forest. Named after Jaffarabad in Gujarat. Found in Amreli, Bhavnagar, Jamnagar, Junagadh, Porbandar, and Rajkot districts.
horns: Large, flat, thick horns curving downward and sideways, then upward and inward, forming a ring-like shape.
purpose: Primarily dairy, also used for draught and meat due to large size.
physical_traits: Massive, muscular frame; males ~700 kg, females ~620 kg; dome-shaped forehead, small eyes.
milk_yield: Average 2239 kg per lactation (7.7% fat). Range 2150–2340 kg.
color: Usually jet black, though some may have a white or grey tail switch.
other_info: Known for strength and endurance; adapted to hot and dry Saurashtra climate; high fat milk yield.

origin: Originated in Bhadawar State (Uttar Pradesh & Madhya Pradesh). Found in Bah (Agra), Chakarnagar, Barhpura (Etawah), Ambah, Porsa (Morena), and Mehgaon (Bhind).
horns: Black horns curving outward, downward, then backward along neck before turning upward at tips.
purpose: Dual-purpose breed for milk and draught; known for high-fat milk.
physical_traits: Medium-sized, compact body, strong limbs, coppery sheen coat; adapted to ravine regions.
milk_yield: Average 1294 kg per lactation; 7.88% fat; up to 12.8% recorded.
color: Blackish copper to light copper; wheat-colored legs; two white lines ('Chevron') on neck.
other_info: Efficient feed converter; uses low-quality roughage; suited to hot, dry climates.

origin: Originated between Sutlej and Ravi rivers in undivided Punjab (India & Pakistan). Found in Amritsar, Gurdaspur, Ferozepur, Lahore, Multan, and Bahawalpur.
horns: Moderately long, flat horns curving backward and outward.
purpose: Primarily dairy breed, high milk quality similar to Murrah.
physical_traits: Large body, walled eyes, soft skin, well-developed udder; similar to Murrah but lighter color.
milk_yield: Average 1850 kg per lactation (6.8% fat).
color: Black with white markings on forehead, muzzle, legs, and tail ('Panch Kalyani'); bluish-white eyes.
other_info: Excellent dairy buffalo; docile, fertile, heat-tolerant; name derived from Sutlej River's blue waters.

origin: Developed by crossing Murrah and Surti breeds; originated in Mehsana district, Gujarat.
horns: Sickle-shaped horns, curving upward more than Surti but less than Murrah.
purpose: Dairy breed valued for high yield and rich milk fat.
physical_traits: Medium-sized, compact, bright bulging eyes, strong body, good udder development.
milk_yield: Average 1988 kg per lactation (5.2–9.5% fat, avg 6.83%).
color: Predominantly black, some black-brown or brown.
other_info: Known for good lactation persistency; hardy and climate-adapted; combines traits of Murrah and Surti.

origin: Originates from Vidarbha region (Akola, Amravati, Yavatmal, Wardha, and Nagpur districts, Maharashtra).
horns: Long, flat, curved backward nearly to shoulders, tips upward.
purpose: Dual-purpose: milk and draught.
physical_traits: Medium-large, sturdy build, long horns, strong limbs, compact body.
milk_yield: Average 1039 kg per lactation (7.0–8.8% fat).
color: Black with white patches on face, legs, and tail tip; Puranthadi strain slightly brownish.
other_info: Adapted to hot, dry Vidarbha climate; low maintenance; efficient; strong draught breed.

origin: Named after Toda tribe of Nilgiri Hills, Tamil Nadu; thrives in high rainfall, humid areas.
horns: Long, thick, outward and upward curving horns forming crescent shape.
purpose: Used for draught, ceremonial, socio-cultural, and religious purposes.
physical_traits: Medium, strong, narrow dense hair band on back, two chevron markings on neck.
milk_yield: Average ~500 kg per lactation (8.22% fat).
color: Calves fawn at birth, turning ash-grey; adults fawn or ash-grey.
other_info: Culturally significant to Toda tribe; well adapted to humid hills; high-fat milk.

origin: Banni area of Kutch district, Gujarat; maintained by Maldharis under extensive night-grazing system
horns: Tightly coiled vertically with single or double coiling
purpose: High milk yield; hardy dairy breed
physical_traits: Medium to large compact body covered with hair; elongated straight forehead; absence of dewlap; medium naval flap; well-developed, round, squarely placed udder with four uniformly developed quarters and conical teats
milk_yield: Average 2857 kg/lactation (range 1095–6054 kg); fat content ~6.65%
color: Mostly black; some copper-colored individuals
other_info: Also known as 'Kutchi' or 'Kundi'; adapted to harsh arid Banni grasslands; grazes at night to avoid heat stress; tolerant to drought and water scarcity; disease-resistant; managed by Maldhari pastoralists using traditional systems

origin: Dangs district of Gujarat; Thane, Nasik, Ahmednagar districts of Maharashtra
horns: Short and thick, tips pointing laterally (some inward or downward)
purpose: Draught purpose – used for ploughing, harrowing, carting timber
physical_traits: Small head with slightly protruding forehead; oily skin secretion protects from rain; adapted to heavy rainfall and hilly regions
milk_yield: Avg. 430 kg/lactation; range 175–800 kg; 4.3% fat
color: White coat with red or black spots unevenly distributed
other_info: Also known as 'Kandadi'; excellent worker in heavy rainfall and rice field areas

origin: Kasaragod district of Kerala; also found in Mangalore, Coorg, and parts of Karnataka
horns: Short to medium, curved upward and outward; variation in length and shape
purpose: Dual-purpose (draught + low-yield milk); ideal for zero-budget farming
physical_traits: Small-sized, well-proportioned; straight forehead; medium horizontal ears; small bowl-shaped udder; long tail; height ~107 cm (males), 95 cm (females); high heat tolerance and disease resistance
milk_yield: Around 1 litre/day; calving interval 15–18 months
color: Usually black or shades of chocolate, brown, or white; spotted variants also seen; black muzzle, eyelids, tail switch, hoofs, and horns
other_info: Also called 'Sahya Pashu'; highly sustainable; thrives on minimal feed; less prone to mastitis; promoted by Kasaragod Dwarf Conservation Society (est. 2010); under study at Bela Cattle Farm, Kerala

origin: Bundelkhand region along river Ken — Panna, Chhatarpur, Tikamgarh (Madhya Pradesh) and Lalitpur, Hamirpur, Banda (Uttar Pradesh)
horns: Emerge from outer angles of poll, directed forward, ending in sharp points
purpose: Draught purpose — used for cultivation in rocky areas and light road work
physical_traits: Small but compact, sturdy body; short and broad head with dished forehead; sharply pointed ears; short but strong limbs; straight back with drooping quarters; hard feet; developed hump; pendulous sheath with black tip; moderate dewlap; medium tail with black switch
milk_yield: 1–3 kg/day (avg. 500–600 kg/lactation over 6–8 months)
color: Various shades of grey and black, rarely white; grey on barrel to dark grey elsewhere
other_info: Extremely hardy; thrives on poor feed and rough terrain; suited for hilly Bundelkhand; declining population due to interbreeding; conservation efforts needed

origin: Kheri district of Uttar Pradesh
horns: Upstanding, curving outward and upward; thick at base
purpose: Draught purpose — bullocks are fast and efficient workers
physical_traits: Small but active animals; compact build suited for field work
milk_yield: 300–500 kg per lactation
color: White coat; some grey shading, especially on face
other_info: Also known as 'Kheri', 'Kharigarh', or 'Khari'; hardy and agile breed adapted to local conditions

origin: Western Ghats region — Chikmagalur, Dakshin Kannada, Hassan, Kodagu, Shimoga, Uttar Kannada, and Udupi districts of Karnataka
horns: Small, straight, outward, upward and inward
purpose: Dual-purpose — milk, manure, and light draught power
physical_traits: Small, compact body (~90 cm tall); black tail switch; small hump; small bowl-shaped udder; hardy and disease resistant
milk_yield: 3–5 kg/day (elite cows); avg. 220 kg/lactation
color: Predominantly black with light fawn shades on thigh and shoulder
other_info: Also called 'Gidda', 'Uradana', 'Varshagandhi'; thrives in zero-input systems; highly adapted to heavy rainfall and hilly terrain

origin: Nagaur District of Rajasthan; also found in Bikaner and Jodhpur districts
horns: Moderate size; emerge from outer angles of poll, curve outward, upward, then inward at tips
purpose: Draught purpose — ploughing, cultivation, transportation; excellent trotters
physical_traits: Fine, big, active yet docile; long deep body; long limbs; straight back; muscular shoulders; small strong hooves; long narrow face; large pendulous ears; well-developed hump; small dewlap; moderate tail with black tuft
milk_yield: Avg. 603 kg/lactation (range: 479–905 kg); 5.8% fat
color: White or grey coat
other_info: Resembles Hariana and Kankrej breeds; hardy and fast; adapted to Rajasthan’s dry climate; used widely for light transport in Rajputana

origin: Nimari tract of Narmada Valley — Barwani, Khargon, Khandwa, parts of Harda (Madhya Pradesh); also in Jalgaon (Maharashtra)
horns: Emerge backward from poll, turn upward, outward, and inward; sometimes copper-colored and pointed
purpose: Dual-purpose — draught and milk; used in agricultural operations and transportation
physical_traits: Medium-sized, compact, muscular; straight back; slightly drooping quarters; long thin tail with black switch; strong hooves; well-developed hump; fine slightly loose skin; well-developed udder
milk_yield: Avg. 767 kg/lactation; 4.9% fat
color: Predominantly red with white splashes; may be black or light red and white (Khamgaon strain) or red with violet/yellow-white (Khamla strain)
other_info: Known as 'Biological Engine of Nimari'; hardy and agile; aggressive temperament; supported under Rashtriya Gokul Mission and NPBB/NPDD for conservation and development

origin: Loonkaransar Tehsil, Bikaner District (Rajasthan); also found in Ganganagar, Jaisalmer (Rajasthan) and Fazilka, Abohar (Punjab)
horns: Short to medium; curving outward, upward, and inward
purpose: Dual-purpose — milk and draught
physical_traits: Medium-sized, symmetrical body; short smooth coat; broad slightly dished face; medium ears and forehead; fine voluminous dewlap; large navel flap; long tapering tail with black or white switch; well-developed udder and milk vein
milk_yield: Avg. 1500 kg/lactation (range 1050–2000 kg); females yield 1325–2093 kg; age at first calving 45–57 months
color: Brown with white patches; sometimes completely brown or black with white patches; lighter underbody
other_info: Originated from mix of Sahiwal, Red Sindhi, Tharparkar, and Dhanni breeds; bred by nomadic Raths tribe; hardy and heat-tolerant; resistant to disease; conservation farms at Bikaner and Hanumangarh; used in crossbreeding programs

origin: Vechur village, Kottayam district (Kerala); also found in Kottayam–Ernakulam–Alappuzha belt and Kasargod district
horns: Small, thin, curving forward and downward; sometimes extremely small or hardly visible
purpose: Milk-purpose (high quality A2 milk with medicinal properties); easy to maintain small cattle
physical_traits: Extremely small-sized breed (average height 87 cm, length 124 cm, weight ≈ 130 kg); compact body; long head with narrow face; short legs; small hump in males; long tapering tail touching ground; small square udder with tapering teats; well-developed milk vein and glossy skin
milk_yield: 2.5–3.5 litres/day; fat content 4.5–5 %; rich in A2 beta casein; calving interval 15–16 months; age at first calving 36–42 months
color: Light red, black, or white; smooth and glossy coat
other_info: Docile, intelligent, disease-resistant (Mastitis, FMD, respiratory infections); requires low feed and veterinary care; easy calving and robust calves (no infant mortality); recognized by FAO as Critical breed; revived by Ms. Sosamma Iype (KAU); ongoing conservation at CASAGB – Kerala Agricultural University

origin: Originated on the Isle of Guernsey in the English Channel (off the coast of France/England).
horns: Typically horned: short, curved horns; some polled lines exist in North America.
purpose: Dairy breed
physical_traits: Medium-sized; cows ~450-500 kg, bulls ~600-700 kg. Good dairy conformation: strong back, wide rump, deep barrel, well-attached udder extending forward, balanced quarters.
milk_yield: Around 6,000 litres/year (~13,200 lbs). Milk has unusually high protein, butterfat, beta-carotene and A2 casein: 12% more protein, 30% more cream, 33% more vitamin D, 25% more vitamin A and 15% more calcium than average milk.
color: Fawn to reddish-brown (yellowish tones) with white patches; sometimes fully solid red or fawn.
other_info: Efficient feed conversion (20-30% less feed per unit milk than larger breeds) when grazing-based. Known for docile temperament, early maturity, easy calving, adaptability to many climates.

origin: Originated in the County of Ayr, Scotland, before 1800 and recognized as an established breed by 1812. Developed through crosses of native Scottish cattle with breeds such as Teeswater and Channel Islands cattle. Formerly called Dunlop and Cunningham before being named Ayrshire. Bred to thrive in the rugged, hilly climate and pastures of Ayrshire, Scotland.
horns: Originally had long, gracefully curved horns (up to a foot long), now mostly dehorned for practicality.
purpose: Specialized dairy breed, known for excellent milk quality and adaptability.
physical_traits: Medium-sized, strong and rugged cattle; mature cows weigh about 550 kg (1,200 lbs); excellent udder conformation with well-attached, high-quality udders; well-balanced frame with strong legs and hooves; thrive in rough terrain; efficient grazers; exhibit vigor and resilience; calves are hardy and easy to rear.
milk_yield: Moderate-to-high production; average of ~12,000 lbs (5,440 kg) milk per lactation with 3.9% butterfat; top producers exceed 20,000 lbs (9,000+ kg), and records reach ~37,000 lbs (16,800 kg) milk with ~1,600 lbs fat.
color: Red and white coat — red may range from light reddish-brown to dark mahogany, sometimes appearing nearly black in bulls; jagged-edged white patches; some have speckled red pigmentation under white hair; brindle or roan patterns were common historically but are now rare.
other_info: Extremely hardy, adaptable, and long-lived; suitable for both intensive and extensive management systems. Known for easy calving, low somatic cell count, and genetic disease resistance. Milk is termed 'the ideal drinking milk' for its balanced fat and protein; preferred in taste tests over Holstein and Jersey milk. High kappa-casein and small fat globules make it ideal for cheese, yogurt, and ice cream. Ayrshire bulls’ progeny are valued for both dairy and beef potential (no yellow tallow). Excellent forage converters, performing well under limited feed conditions.
